Reviews.Content: The hotel was as expected from a chain. Comfortable room, good sized TV etc. Breakfast had a lot of variety though have had better and was expensive at 9Euro. It was a bit of a walk to the main sites but not far. Not much in the vicinity of the hotel. Nothing to fault at all, just lacked character.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay within short distance of the centre.”
Reviews.Author: Leanne0117
Reviews.Content: Pro's - A lovely, new and modern hotel. Room was spotlessly clean and well presented. Free internet access - they have a terminal to use if you don't have a laptop with you. U-Bahn at end of the street and only 3 stops from Alexanderplatz - though you can take a nice, safe walk there in 15 minutes. Con's - Staff could be more cheerful. In a quiet location - if you want to be in the thick of the action, restaurants, bars etc., stay somewhere else. Having said this - if you are staying during the week - lots of building work going on around the hotel - quite noisy in mornings but you'll have been woken up by the noisy housekeepers anyway so it won't really matter!! These were only minor downsides to staying at this hotel and they really didn't detract from what was a great stay.

Reviews.Title: “more than enough”
Reviews.Author: lidaGreece
Reviews.Content: I would definately recommend this hotel!Its location is great,close to the center of East Berlin, near Alexanderplatz. Although the room is quite small it is cossy and clean. Last, I would say that its price is not reflected in its value as it offers more than enough.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel + disabled review.”
Reviews.Author: AOulton
Reviews.Content: Great hotel, quiet location but only 5 minutes away from Alexanderplatz. A 5 minute walk from the U2 line (and I walk very slowly!) The staff were lovely and very helpful, they were able to recommend places to eat, call taxis, and booked a table for us at the TV tower. Although there was not that much in the immediate vicinity there was a really good and reasonably priced tapas restaurant opposite - which had live music on the night we went. There was also a little bakery opposite, I would recommend skipping the breakfast, which although I'm sure was very good, came up at €9pp. The cakes opposite were 90cents! Under a mile away was 4 or 5 restaurants, a taxi there was not much, or it would be easy to find walking (ask for mutter hoppe - only go there if you are really REALLY hungry though!!!) I'm not sure what most of the rooms are like as I had a disabled room, I think maybe just slightly smaller however the room was very clean, had its own thermostat and the beds were amazing! The hotel is so new nothing has a chance to feel shabby yet...go there while it still feels luxury! I would definitely recommend this hotel, it's extremely comfortable, in a nice quiet area but with a central location and very close to the underground line. The staff were really helpful and I got the hotel for less than I would have paid for a not such a safe bet, privately run hotel in a dodgy area! Points for disabled travelers: The hotel itself is completely accessible, with lifts and level entry etc. There are 8 accessible rooms which were really good, they were easily wide enough to get a wheelchair around (although you would be limited to one side of the bed - which were 2 twins pushed together) The bathroom was a large wetroom, the shower was amazingly powerful, the floor was total non slip and there was a seat that could be slid along the rail to be under the shower or out of the way. The toilet was a little terrifying at first as they had raised the toilet seat from underneath with a bucket like contraption, so you still sat on the normal toilet seat. Actually I think that system is much better than the weird extender seats you get in england though. The room itself had no hand rails or anything, only the bathroom. The toilet was in the middle of the wall with lifting handrails on each side, so a wheelchair transfer would be possible from either side. Although it was well kitted out for a disabled user, the place didn't feel like a hospital, which was nice!! As far as the area goes, the street to the u station probably wasn't very useful for a wheelchair user - It was cobbled, drop kerbs not in useful places etc. However it was a very very quiet wide street that you could just go in the road with no issue. I am not in a wheelchair and found the walk to the underground station fairly easy (it's about 100m) There was a lift down to the underground (which you have to walk a little further for). I think I only went to one station that wasn't disabled/wheelchair accessible - and that was a random one right in the countryside (don't ask!). Generally Berlin was very disabled accessible. The public transport was all enabled for wheelchair users. Although the trams said they were, you have to go out into the middle of the road and they are pretty high up - so not sure how that works. Most of the transport was easy to get on and off with mobility impairments, except the tram, which involved a large step! I can't remember what the access into the tapas place opposite was like, but they had a disabled toilet so i'm going to presume it was ok! Generally most of the places we went were disabled friendly, unfortunately the TV tower was not wheelchair accessible and I encountered a very very unhelpful man at the berlin documentation centre (opposite the berlin wall) who would let me go up to the viewing tower in the lift but wouldn't let me come down - because it was 15 minutes before closing and he was turning the lift off! The restaurant mutterhoppe had a flight of stairs (although large and a good banister) and the 'story of berlin' had about 5 steps that had to be done (although they were very nice in there) One last note - When I went to berlin I was planning on borrowing wheelchairs in the galleries so I wasn't in so much pain. Alhough it is very common to find wheelchairs you can borrow in english museums, this doesn't seam to be the way in germany. The only place that had a wheelchair was the bauhaus archiv museum, which I would highly recommend as they were so lovely (before they realised they did have a wheelchair, they gave me a chair for my brother to carry around!) Sorry that's a bit of an essay, but I hope it helps make your decision a bit easier!

Reviews.Title: “Very comfy, modern, but not perfect... yet”
Reviews.Author: love_to_travel
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed our stay at this hotel despite a few issues. Pros: -Very close to U-Bahn, a block and a half away -U-Bahn is only 3 stations from Alexanderplatz -Brand new hotel, modern and clean -Comfortable beds -Receptionists were very nice Cons: -Problems with heating, was like a sauna, humidity level way too high -Although very nice, receptionists not very knowledgeable -Couldn't find any convenient stores around hotel

Reviews.Title: “Nice clean hotel in a quiet area”
Reviews.Author: NeRudeBoy
Reviews.Content: Staff were very polite and helpful. The room was very clean. Hotel is close to the U-Bahn and a nice Tapas bar, but apart from that there is very little around the area other than office buildings (so no final bars or late night snacks when you return to the area). Breakfast was nice enough and reasonable value at €9. We stayed in the other section, so we had to go through the breakfast area and then turn right into another building before using the lift/stairs. I got used to it, but I imagine older guests might not want to go through so many heavy doors to get to and from their room. Negative points are, the beds were fairly narrow, a wider bed would have been more comfortable and the hotel should offer some light snacks (e.g. sandwiches) since there's nowhere in the area to eat late. If you want a nice, reasonably priced, clean hotel in a quiet area that's still connected to the transport system, then I would recommend this one. If you want to be in the thick of the bar action then look for places in Nord Mitte or Prenzlauer Berg.

Reviews.Title: “A Work In Progress”
Reviews.Author: comfortzone_7
Reviews.Content: This hotel is located in a nice area of berlin near the ubahn station of spittelmarkt.it was clean, the rooms are a bit small but suitable for a city break. However when myself and two friends booked what was advertised on their website ( namely two double rooms with connecting door) on arrival we found that this was not the case, in fact they did not have this type of accommodation at all despite having written confirmation to the contrary. After a couple of hours deliberation we were finally accommodated. this hotel opened in my opinion too early and was not ready to receive guests. The breakfast area is located two sides of a passway in the lower basement of the hotel. found this a bit claustophobic. Reception staff do not comnmunicate with each other when trying to solve a problem that did arise when we stayed there. with time and effort this could improve and maybe this hotel will rise in its rating.
